trans-unit.source: Build your first Azure Data Factory pipeline using Azure PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Build your first Azure Data Factory pipeline using Azure PowerShell

trans-unit.source: In this tutorial, you will create a sample Azure Data Factory pipeline using Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: In this tutorial, you will create a sample Azure Data Factory pipeline using Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: In this article, you will learn how to use Azure PowerShell to create your first pipeline.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you will learn how to use Azure PowerShell to create your first pipeline.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial consists of the following steps:
trans-unit.target: This tutorial consists of the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Creating the data factory.
trans-unit.target: Creating the data factory.

trans-unit.source: Creating the linked services (data stores, computes) and datasets.
trans-unit.target: Creating the linked services (data stores, computes) and datasets.

trans-unit.source: Creating the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Creating the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: This article does not provide a conceptual overview of the Azure Data Factory service.
trans-unit.target: This article does not provide a conceptual overview of the Azure Data Factory service.

trans-unit.source: For a detailed overview of the service, see the <linkText>Introduction to Azure Data Factory</linkText><title></title> article.
trans-unit.target: For a detailed overview of the service, see the <linkText>Introduction to Azure Data Factory</linkText><title></title> article.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you use Azure PowerShell to create an Azure Data Factory named ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you use Azure PowerShell to create an Azure Data Factory named ADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH.

trans-unit.source: Start Azure PowerShell and run the following commands.
trans-unit.target: Start Azure PowerShell and run the following commands.

trans-unit.source: Keep Azure PowerShell open until the end of this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Keep Azure PowerShell open until the end of this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: If you close and reopen, you need to run these commands again.
trans-unit.target: If you close and reopen, you need to run these commands again.

trans-unit.source: Run Add-AzureAccount and enter the user name and password that you use to sign in to the Azure preview portal.
trans-unit.target: Run Add-AzureAccount and enter the user name and password that you use to sign in to the Azure preview portal.

trans-unit.source: Run Get-AzureSubscription to view all the subscriptions for this account.
trans-unit.target: Run Get-AzureSubscription to view all the subscriptions for this account.

trans-unit.source: Run Select-AzureSubscription to select the subscription that you want to work with.
trans-unit.target: Run Select-AzureSubscription to select the subscription that you want to work with.

trans-unit.source: This subscription should be the same as the one you used in the preview portal.
trans-unit.target: This subscription should be the same as the one you used in the preview portal.

trans-unit.source: Switch to AzureResourceManager mode as the Azure Data Factory cmdlets are available in this mode.
trans-unit.target: Switch to AzureResourceManager mode as the Azure Data Factory cmdlets are available in this mode.

trans-unit.source: Create an Azure resource group named ADFTutorialResourceGroup by running the following command.
trans-unit.target: Create an Azure resource group named ADFTutorialResourceGroup by running the following command.

trans-unit.source: Some of the steps in this tutorial assume that you use the resource group named ADFTutorialResourceGroup.
trans-unit.target: Some of the steps in this tutorial assume that you use the resource group named ADFTutorialResourceGroup.

trans-unit.source: If you use a different resource group, you will need to use it in place of ADFTutorialResourceGroup in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: If you use a different resource group, you will need to use it in place of ADFTutorialResourceGroup in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Run the New-AzureDataFactory cmdlet to create a data factory named DataFactoryMyFirstPipelinePSH.
trans-unit.target: Run the New-AzureDataFactory cmdlet to create a data factory named DataFactoryMyFirstPipelinePSH.

trans-unit.source: The name of the Azure Data Factory must be globally unique.
trans-unit.target: The name of the Azure Data Factory must be globally unique.

trans-unit.source: If you receive the error Data factory name “DataFactoryMyFirstPipelinePSH” is not available, change the name (for example, yournameADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH).
trans-unit.target: If you receive the error Data factory name “DataFactoryMyFirstPipelinePSH” is not available, change the name (for example, yournameADFTutorialDataFactoryPSH).

trans-unit.source: Use this name in place of ADFTutorialFactoryPSH while performing steps in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: Use this name in place of ADFTutorialFactoryPSH while performing steps in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In the subsequent steps, you will learn how to create the linked services, datasets and pipeline that you will use in this tutorial.
trans-unit.target: In the subsequent steps, you will learn how to create the linked services, datasets and pipeline that you will use in this tutorial.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will link your Azure Storage account and an on-demand Azure HDInsight cluster to your data factory and then create a dataset to represent the output data from Hive processing.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will link your Azure Storage account and an on-demand Azure HDInsight cluster to your data factory and then create a dataset to represent the output data from Hive processing.

trans-unit.source: Create a JSON file named StorageLinkedService.json in the C:\ADFGetStartedPSH folder with the following content.
trans-unit.target: Create a JSON file named StorageLinkedService.json in the C:\ADFGetStartedPSH folder with the following content.

trans-unit.source: Create the folder ADFGetStartedPSH if it does not already exist.
trans-unit.target: Create the folder ADFGetStartedPSH if it does not already exist.

trans-unit.source: Replace account name with the name of your Azure storage account and account key with the access key of the Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: Replace account name with the name of your Azure storage account and account key with the access key of the Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: To learn how to get your storage access key, see <linkText>View, copy and regenerate storage access keys</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To learn how to get your storage access key, see <linkText>View, copy and regenerate storage access keys</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In Azure PowerShell, switch to the ADFGetStartedPSH folder.
trans-unit.target: In Azure PowerShell, switch to the ADFGetStartedPSH folder.

trans-unit.source: You can use the New-AzureDataFactoryLinkedService cmdlet to create a linked service.
trans-unit.target: You can use the New-AzureDataFactoryLinkedService cmdlet to create a linked service.

trans-unit.source: This cmdlet and other Data Factory cmdlets you use in this tutorial require you to pass values for the ResourceGroupName and DataFactoryName parameters.
trans-unit.target: This cmdlet and other Data Factory cmdlets you use in this tutorial require you to pass values for the ResourceGroupName and DataFactoryName parameters.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you can use Get-AzureDataFactory to get a DataFactory object and pass the object without typing ResourceGroupName and DataFactoryName each time you run a cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you can use Get-AzureDataFactory to get a DataFactory object and pass the object without typing ResourceGroupName and DataFactoryName each time you run a cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to assign the output of the Get-AzureDataFactory cmdlet to a $df variable.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to assign the output of the Get-AzureDataFactory cmdlet to a $df variable.

trans-unit.source: Now, run the New-AzureDataFactoryLinkedService cmdlet to create the linked StorageLinkedService service.
trans-unit.target: Now, run the New-AzureDataFactoryLinkedService cmdlet to create the linked StorageLinkedService service.

trans-unit.source: If you hadn't run the Get-AzureDataFactory cmdlet and assigned the output to the $df variable, you would have to specify values for the ResourceGroupName and DataFactoryName parameters as follows.
trans-unit.target: If you hadn't run the Get-AzureDataFactory cmdlet and assigned the output to the $df variable, you would have to specify values for the ResourceGroupName and DataFactoryName parameters as follows.

trans-unit.source: If you close Azure PowerShell in the middle of the tutorial, you will have run the Get-AzureDataFactory cmdlet next time you start Azure PowerShell to complete the tutorial.
trans-unit.target: If you close Azure PowerShell in the middle of the tutorial, you will have run the Get-AzureDataFactory cmdlet next time you start Azure PowerShell to complete the tutorial.

trans-unit.source: Now, you will create a linked service for an on-demand Azure HDInsight cluster that will be used to run the Hive script.
trans-unit.target: Now, you will create a linked service for an on-demand Azure HDInsight cluster that will be used to run the Hive script.

trans-unit.source: Create a JSON file named HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService.json in the C:\ADFGetStartedPSH folder with the following content.
trans-unit.target: Create a JSON file named HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService.json in the C:\ADFGetStartedPSH folder with the following content.

trans-unit.source: The following table provides descriptions for the JSON properties used in the snippet:
trans-unit.target: The following table provides descriptions for the JSON properties used in the snippet:

trans-unit.source: Property | Description -------- | ----------- Version | This specifies that the version of the HDInsight created to be 3.1.
trans-unit.target: Property | Description -------- | ----------- Version | This specifies that the version of the HDInsight created to be 3.1.

trans-unit.source: ClusterSize | This creates a one node HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: ClusterSize | This creates a one node HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: TimeToLive | This specifies that the idle time for the HDInsight cluster, before it is deleted.
trans-unit.target: TimeToLive | This specifies that the idle time for the HDInsight cluster, before it is deleted.

trans-unit.source: JobsContainer | This specifies the name of the job container that will be created to store the logs that are generated by HDInsight linkedServiceName | This specifies the storage account that will be used to store the logs that are generated by HDInsight
trans-unit.target: JobsContainer | This specifies the name of the job container that will be created to store the logs that are generated by HDInsight linkedServiceName | This specifies the storage account that will be used to store the logs that are generated by HDInsight

trans-unit.source: Run the New-AzureDataFactoryLinkedService cmdlet to create the linked service called HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService.
trans-unit.target: Run the New-AzureDataFactoryLinkedService cmdlet to create the linked service called HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService.

trans-unit.source: Now, you will create the output dataset to represent the data stored in the Azure Blob storage.
trans-unit.target: Now, you will create the output dataset to represent the data stored in the Azure Blob storage.

trans-unit.source: Create a JSON file named OutputTable.json in the C:\ADFGetStartedPSH folder with the following content:
trans-unit.target: Create a JSON file named OutputTable.json in the C:\ADFGetStartedPSH folder with the following content:

trans-unit.source: In the previous example, you are creating a dataset called AzureBlobOutput, and specifying the structure of the data that will be produced by the Hive script.
trans-unit.target: In the previous example, you are creating a dataset called AzureBlobOutput, and specifying the structure of the data that will be produced by the Hive script.

trans-unit.source: In addition, you specify that the results are stored in the blob container called data and the folder called partitioneddata.
trans-unit.target: In addition, you specify that the results are stored in the blob container called data and the folder called partitioneddata.

trans-unit.source: The availability section specifies that the output dataset is produced on a monthly basis.
trans-unit.target: The availability section specifies that the output dataset is produced on a monthly basis.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command in Azure PowerShell to create the Data Factory table.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command in Azure PowerShell to create the Data Factory table.

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will create your first pipeline.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will create your first pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Create a JSON file named MyFirstPipelinePSH.json in the C:\ADFGetStartedPSH folder with the following content:
trans-unit.target: Create a JSON file named MyFirstPipelinePSH.json in the C:\ADFGetStartedPSH folder with the following content:

trans-unit.source: Replace storageaccountname with the name of your storage account in the JSON.
trans-unit.target: Replace storageaccountname with the name of your storage account in the JSON.

trans-unit.source: In the previous example, you are creating a pipeline that consists of a single activity that uses Hive to process data on an HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: In the previous example, you are creating a pipeline that consists of a single activity that uses Hive to process data on an HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: The Hive script file, partitionweblogs.hql, is stored in the Azure storage account (specified by the scriptLinkedService, called StorageLinkedService), and in a container called script.
trans-unit.target: The Hive script file, partitionweblogs.hql, is stored in the Azure storage account (specified by the scriptLinkedService, called StorageLinkedService), and in a container called script.

trans-unit.source: The extendedProperties section is used to specify the runtime settings that will be passed to the hive script as Hive configuration values (for example, ${hiveconf:PartitionedData}).
trans-unit.target: The extendedProperties section is used to specify the runtime settings that will be passed to the hive script as Hive configuration values (for example, ${hiveconf:PartitionedData}).

trans-unit.source: The start and end properties of the pipeline specifies the active period of the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: The start and end properties of the pipeline specifies the active period of the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: In the activity JSON, you specify that the Hive script runs on the computer specified by the linked service – HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService.
trans-unit.target: In the activity JSON, you specify that the Hive script runs on the computer specified by the linked service – HDInsightOnDemandLinkedService.

trans-unit.source: Run the following command to create the Data Factory table.
trans-unit.target: Run the following command to create the Data Factory table.

trans-unit.source: Congratulations, you have successfully created your first pipeline using Azure PowerShell!
trans-unit.target: Congratulations, you have successfully created your first pipeline using Azure PowerShell!

trans-unit.source: In this step, you will use Azure PowerShell to monitor what’s going on in an Azure data factory.
trans-unit.target: In this step, you will use Azure PowerShell to monitor what’s going on in an Azure data factory.

trans-unit.source: Run Get-AzureDataFactory and assign the output to a $df variable.
trans-unit.target: Run Get-AzureDataFactory and assign the output to a $df variable.

trans-unit.source: Run Get-AzureDataFactorySlice to get details about all slices of the EmpSQLTable, which is the output table of the pipeline.
trans-unit.target: Run Get-AzureDataFactorySlice to get details about all slices of the EmpSQLTable, which is the output table of the pipeline.

trans-unit.source: Notice that the StartDateTime you specify here is the same start time specified in the pipeline JSON.
trans-unit.target: Notice that the StartDateTime you specify here is the same start time specified in the pipeline JSON.

trans-unit.source: You should see output similar to the following.
trans-unit.target: You should see output similar to the following.

trans-unit.source: Run Get-AzureDataFactoryRun to get the details of activity runs for a specific slice.
trans-unit.target: Run Get-AzureDataFactoryRun to get the details of activity runs for a specific slice.

trans-unit.source: You should see output similar to the following.
trans-unit.target: You should see output similar to the following.

trans-unit.source: You can keep running this cmdlet until you see the slice in Ready state or Failed state.
trans-unit.target: You can keep running this cmdlet until you see the slice in Ready state or Failed state.

trans-unit.source: When the slice is in Ready state, check the partitioneddata folder in the data container in your blob storage for the output data.
trans-unit.target: When the slice is in Ready state, check the partitioneddata folder in the data container in your blob storage for the output data.

trans-unit.source: Note that the creation of an on-demand HDInsight cluster usually takes some time.
trans-unit.target: Note that the creation of an on-demand HDInsight cluster usually takes some time.

trans-unit.source: See <linkText>Data Factory Cmdlet Reference</linkText><title></title> for comprehensive documentation on Data Factory cmdlets.
trans-unit.target: See <linkText>Data Factory Cmdlet Reference</linkText><title></title> for comprehensive documentation on Data Factory cmdlets.

trans-unit.source: In this article, you have created a pipeline with a transformation activity (HDInsight Activity) that runs a Hive script on an on-demand Azure HDInsight cluster.
trans-unit.target: In this article, you have created a pipeline with a transformation activity (HDInsight Activity) that runs a Hive script on an on-demand Azure HDInsight cluster.

trans-unit.source: To see how to use a Copy Activity to copy data from an Azure Blob to Azure SQL, see <linkText>Tutorial: Copy data from an Azure Blob to Azure SQL</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: To see how to use a Copy Activity to copy data from an Azure Blob to Azure SQL, see <linkText>Tutorial: Copy data from an Azure Blob to Azure SQL</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: We would really appreciate your feedback on this article.
trans-unit.target: We would really appreciate your feedback on this article.

trans-unit.source: Please take a few minutes to submit your feedback via <linkText>email</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Please take a few minutes to submit your feedback via <linkText>email</linkText><title></title>.
